Cedar Shakes
Dirt, Mildew, Water Stains
& Chalking
How to clean siding is sometimes
hard to explain since there are many
things that can stain or discolor the
finish materials. Here is a brief explainationof the main 4 reasons for discoloration on siding finishes, and how you may go about cleaning them...
DIRT
This one is easy to clean, and less harmful than the others. A mild detergent and soft bristled brush usually does the trick! Pressure washing is NOT recommended for any painted surface, since the high pressure can easily destroy and cause flaking.
MILDEW
Mildew usually effects both the finish and the wood. Mildew is a common cause of discoloration and deterioration of paint, solid-color stains and natural finishes. Repainting the siding will not solve a mildew problem, even if you clean the siding first. When it is time to refinish, use a commercial mildew-remover to clean the siding. Refinish with a coating that contains an effective mildewcide that can easily be purchased and mixed from the paint supplier. Mildew issues can easily happen on any home, however homes built on heavily wooded lots or near lakes, rivers and streams are highly at risk.
WATER STAINS
Trouble usually comes in pairs... water stains usually are visible where there has been a mildew issue. It can be an equal challenge to successfully clean. There are specific chemicals (special blend acids) that may be obtained for these type stains. Carefully follow the instructions with the cleaner you purchase. Consult with a paint specialist to determine which cleaner is right for your type home and siding application.
CHALKING
Chalking is a property of the paint, not the wood or siding. As paint film weathers or deteriorates it sometimes releases pigment particles that act like a fine powder on the paint surface. Chalking is a common cause of fading of tinted or colored paints. Discoloration from this type stain is highly apparent when dark paint is used on exterior trim over light colored material surrounding it. An example would be
navy blue paint on window shutters installed on a white stucco wall. The stucco will usually have a streaking effect appear below the shutters in the form of a stain that can be very difficult to remove. Again, consult with a paint specialist to determine which cleaner is right for your type home and application.
After a good cleaning, periodically inspect the siding to make sure that caulking and paint is in good condition. Always keep caulking in good repair around window and door frames, siding end joints & cornerboards. Set nails that may have "popped" out slightly from normal shrinkage and expansion of wood materials that the siding is attached to. If paint is starting to peel in a few areas, always sand the area smooth prior to repainting.
